title: Backwards language
description: This took me a long time! Ultimately it came down to me not realizing that I needed to set my variable to equal the length of the answer.  After that it worked! Now I don't have as much time to make it fancy, but I'm proud of myself for learning!
instructions: I wanted to try to do a backward word generator using strings. This is what I created!

title: The A-to-Z Game
description:
I don't know if I had a "biggest challenge" today. I played it pretty safe, picking a project I had a good idea how I'd build. I had a few problems with initializing data (e.g., adding to lists without emptying them out), but I squashed those bugs relatively quickly. I have no idea what inspired the glass in glasses. :)

Music from the Atlantic Dance Orchestra, Tell Me With Smiles: https://archive.org/details/ReallyOldRecordingsSetA/AtlanticDanceOrchestra-TellMeWithSmiles1923edisonCylinder.mp3
instructions: This is one of my favorite games to play—press green flag to start!

title: Colorful sound
description: I had seen a previous project (Maybe the hexapath remix I did?) where a user typed in some binary (1s and 0s) in order to affect the project. What if a user could type in numbers and make some sounds happen? I had a grand vision of being able to generate strings, and perhaps "pluck" them somewhat...Anyway, I figured out how to store a username + sequence of sounds but didn't have time to sort out the playback. Oh well!
instructions: Press the green flag and follow along! Hover over the strings to play some notes back (this only works sometimes, and for some reason really softly).

title: Chromophobia Weaving
description:
When @karenb shared Chromophobia on Day 15, inspired by Josef Albers, I wondered how I might create a project inspired by both Josef and Anni Albers, combining chromophobia and weaving! Today seemed the perfect day, using list data to create potentially-hideous (and potentially pleasing) color combinations in weave structures, depending on your input!

The life once-considered and yet-to-be-lived in which I was a math major and the life I instead lived at art school as a textiles major are both very excited about this project. This might be the Getting Unstuck project I'm most proud of so far (:

Some stuck moments (of which there were certainly a handful) along the way included initially programming with pen drawing and struggling to get the layering to successfully simulate the weave structure I had in mind (a classic plain weave). At that point I thought maybe I'd set for transparency and realized pen drawings are only opaque. After a brief moment of AHHHH, I realized I could create a long 'thread' sprite which could be transparent, take color data, and be stamped (: 
(any tips on starting to explore layers in scratch would be much appreciated)

This was definitely part of continuing to explore my "where could I get with programming if I don't focus on drawing...?" question.
This also felt like something of a redemption from pattern-drawing-day disasters.

weaving sound:
https://freesound.org/people/xserra/sounds/320510/
instructions:
Press the green flag, enter some data, and see the weave structure you've made!

Wanna make another? Press the space bar (:

Update: I switched the color of the origin sprite -- I learned that this will determine the range of colors for the "color effect"
Is it more or less likely to be hideous now? 
(definitely looking to maximize hideous - beautiful range)

title: Memory Game
description:
This project was created for Day 17 of Getting Unstuck. Today's challenge was to make a project that asks the user for a list and does something interesting with it. There are multiple lists in this project, and I had a really big bug in one of them that took me 20 minutes to figure out (sheesh!). But I got to reuse a bunch of graphics and scripts from previous Getting Unstuck projects, and I had a lot of fun making it!

Music: 4bstr4ck3r, "Soundboy"
instructions: Press the green flag to play!

title: Be a judge on the voice! getting unstuck day 17
description: Using lists is one of my favourite ways to personalize projects so I enjoyed this task! I'm actually working on creating a lesson plan for students to make a project like this, so please let me know what you think and how it can be improved.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 17
description: Shame about having to subtract 1 from the i variable, will look into that some more...

title: Unstuck Day 16/17- Text Input
description:
This was for the Getting Unstuck challenge Day 16 but turned into a big project that I didn't have time to finish in one day. Luckily the next day challenge pretty much fits the bill as well, so it covers Day 17, too!
I have made and taught a hangman game in Python so I thought this would be doable but ran into many many problems. One was not planning carefully enough in the beginning. I was taking out random letters instead of all occurrences of specific letters.
Then Scratch does not have indexed loops (for loops) so I had to make various counters to do things based on the the current loop number. 
I have not used Snap much but this would be a good project for Snap as it would have been useful to have custom blocks that can report something. In Scratch I had to create many variables to keep track of little tasks that would have been easier with reporting blocks.
instructions:
Play Guess the Word! This is for two players, one to type the secret word and the other to guess. Have fun!
If you want to see something cool click "under the hood" while you play and you can see the program processing the tasks as you give it input.
Note: The reason your word can't be a phrase is the program knows when you have guessed the word by checking if it has no more spaces in it, so the spaces would keep you from every being finished.

title: Getting Unstuck #17
description:
This was going to be the Swedish chef, but my digital citizenship got the better of me. 
The last bit of the list, where all the rest of the ingredients are added I couldn't figure out how to get an "and" in there to make it grammatically correct. I'm sure there's a way by carefully counting the ingredients and making sure that the last of them is added by itself, but I couldn't figure it out. If I devote some more time to it in the morning I might get there.

description: Credits: This is a Code Club project resource I used with 4th graders to make poetry in ELA class (projects can be found here https://scratch.mit.edu/studios/4586131/) The students, working in pairs, had to generate and code their list of words. title: Unstuck 17 Binary Bitmap Art
description:
Sample digits to enter: 7 e 8 1 a 5 a 5 8 1 b d 8 1 7 e
Another sample: 9 9 2 4 4 2 9 9 9 9 4 2 2 4 9 9

The activity that inspired this program is a Binary Bitmaps activity (http://cse4k12.org/binary/bitmaps.html) posted by Gary Kacmarcik on cse4k12.org and licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported License (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/). 

For binary/hexadecimal conversion practice, check out this project from gerogero: https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/19900885/
instructions:
This is a program that can check the hexadecimal numbers that are generated as part of a binary bitmap activity. 
Students create a picture on an 8x8 grid then convert the picture into binary numbers; an empty square on the grid is assigned the value 0 and a filled square is assigned the value 1. Each row has eight digits. If you split each row into two four-digit binary numbers you can then convert each row into a two-digit hexadecimal number. 
This program asks the user to enter the 16 hexadecimal digits, one at a time, and then will print the bitmap picture on an 8x8 grid on the stage.
I could modify the code so the user inputs all 16 hexadecimals at once. Does that make more sense that one digit at a time?

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 17 — Word Randomizer
description:
Reflection

Playing with variables, lists, and data can be a lot of fun. I liked the challenge of creating a define block for splitting a string into individual words and placing them into a list. I also like creating the second define block that makes a new string by randomizing the order in which the words are removed from the list.
instructions: Tell Scratch Cat a sentence, and they will randomize the order of the words.

title: Getting Unstuck day 17
description:
I wanted to try to work with some of the list blocks that I have not used before. I hit on the idea of using the length of the words given by the user to play particular notes. This ended up using more block than I expected. I needed a variable to itereate over the list and another to add the notes to the second list. 

With more time I would try to make the output a bit more consistently melodious. Possibly by using addition rather than multiplication to se the notes. Also, I think it might help if the note length is not random, or at least less random.

follow the cat's instructions
change the instrument with the slider.

title: Bug Party planner (Getting Unstuck Day 17)
description:
This is my fifth Unstuck project (three of them are shared on my other account @juf-Pinky). If you encounter a real bug, please let me know.

This was super fun to make. At first I had no idea what to make for this challenge. I wanted to do something with a dance, but I couldn't figure out in which way I could ask the user how the sprite should dance. Then I came up with the idea of a party planner. Using a list turned out to be really useful in this project. I only faced some minor bugs :) Testing all the options was time consuming though. Maybe I missed a bug... This project took me about three hours to make.

Thanks to @Mittensbrother and the Getting Unstuck team for the bug and the Unstuck logo, thanks to @ceebee for the dancing code, thanks to @chrisg for the dancing flower, thanks to @TheDiamonGamer  for the idea of the dancing pizza, thanks to @Bubblebomb for the idea of the dancing stickman. Thanks to @scratchcat for the cool Scratch cat sprites, and thanks to @TheLibrary for the code blocks I used for the confett.
instructions:
Plan your own Bug Party. Please answer the questions of the bug.


I made this for Day 17 of Getting Unstuck! The challenge of today:

title: Drawing clones
description:
Did you know that EVERY rectangular slot in Scratch could be filled with a variable or a list element? Messages or go to something, for example. In this demo I have inserted a list element inside the clone function.

I wonder if these "hidden" features were left on purpose to exercise our "lateral thinking".
instructions:
Choose what to clone by answering the question. You can answer multiple times. When you're ready, just press enter and the clones will be created!
Use only lower case letters!

Once the clones are created, press space for drawing!

title: Challenge 17 - list sorting
description:
Wasn't sure what to do with this one today as I created 3 6000 line lists yesterday which I used Python to extract the data I needed from the raw data to import, a bit exhausting. 

Then I saw today's challenge...haha, LISTS! I was a day early. So I thought I'd work with some sorting. I had to use the Scratch wiki on the insertion sort as I haven't done those sorting methods in a few years. Good to freshen up on them and now I will create some more practice sorting for myself.
instructions:
The program will ask you how many numbers you want. I used a custom block without screen refresh for some parts, others I left there so the lists could be seen what they are performing.

Second you'll ask what you want to count by. If you put 3, the separated list will count by 3s, any other number will be sorted to an odd or even list. 

Then the list will shuffle randomly. Give you a heads up about sorting it and it will using insertion sort method to put it back in order. I used without screen refresh as the sorting took a while, this way it is just done.

title: interest rate arbitrage
description:
For Day 17 of GettingUnstuck, in which we work with Lists.

Spreadsheets are an evocative object for me, so I was excited to use Scratch as a similar medium. I also wanted a visual to support a financial argument (an elective cash out mortgage can be sensible) that is anathema to common sense. 

A more refined model would ask for tax rates on dividends/income and would adjust for tax deductibility of interest payments on the mortgage. Mortgages are structured so that interest repayment is weighted toward the start of the loan and principal repayment is weighted toward the tail, which is advantageous to arbitrage but feels unfair if your goal is to get out of debt. A more refined model would also fluctuate the investment returns.

When I have more time I'd like to develop this so one could track payments in real time of an actual (theoretical) loan against a (paper) investment as well as against speculation, as well as spending opportunity costs, e.g. lattes vs. additional principal repayment.

I tried a formula for calculating mortgage payments, based on https://www.mtgprofessor.com/formulas.htm, and it indicated a monthly payment that was 100 more per month than the PMT function indicated by Excel. This eliminated the arbitrage opportunity, so for this simulation I input the Excel PMT result to Scratch. I left a draft block showing how the inflated payment was calculated. If anyone can find an error there, I would love to understand what it is!
instructions:
Green flag, and watch. This is a crude calculator that simulates mortgage payments balanced against a dividend yielding investment (or interest rate arbitrage). Exponential growth is visually understated (I divided results by 3) so that I could keep visuals on the stage.

Assumptions: 100,000 borrowed for 360 months at an interest rate of 4.7%. Invested in a vehicle that pays annualized 7.1% before taxes via monthly payments. (I used DNP's price and monthly dividends for this model.) Monthly dividends minus pmts are reinvested in the vehicle (no transaction costs assumed).

title: Getting Unstuck #17: Greek Olympiad in Informatics:
description:
Special thanks to Scratch wiki editors for providing useful tips here: http://wiki.scratch.mit.edu/wiki/List

Day #17 Challenge of "Getting Unstuck" project of the Creative Computing Lab at the Harvard Graduate School of Education: Create a project that asks the user to type in multiple words or numbers, stores the items in a list, then does something interesting with the items from the list.
instructions:
Press the green flag and then, the spacebar to continue.

The program prompts you to enter numbers which represent pupils' heights and stores them in a list. Then, it finds the total number of students who can see the school cafeteria while they are standing in line. 
This Scratch project implements the same efficient algorithm which solves the programming exercise that is described here: http://www.pdp.gr/files/27A/PDP_27_A.pdf. Normally, these kind of exercises have a C++ implementation.

title: Day 17: (v2) Sum of Three Positive One-Digit Numbers
description:
What I was was trying to accomplish here . . . 
This second version has dialogue that considers many options; response when user doesn't press space bar to begin, when user types nonsense, when user types numbers other than whole numbers from 1-9, and when user types different variations of "yes" or "no" responses (e.g. yes/YES/Y/y)to continue. It was far more complicated than it needed to be, but I wanted to practise using many of the skills introduced in recent challenges, like broadcast, strings, lists, and answer boxes.  Some coding mistakes I have been making include incorrect use of blocks with "and wait" phrasing, and confusion over when to use answer boxes, variable boxes and how to effectively use lists.  My code made use of several lists with one number in them and a list to add the other lists.  I would much prefer to enter three numbers into one list and find the total of items in that list (but am happy to save that task for another day). Still not sure about the purple "Make a block" and "Add an Extension" blocks.  Not fancy, but I like it :)
instructions:

title: GCF and LCM: Getting Unstuck Day 17 Lists
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 17 Lists

In grade 7 math, we teach students to move away from making lists of multiples when finding the LCM, because it can get long with large numbers or 3 or more numbers, and students risk making mistakes with their multiples, leading to an error in their LCM. We teach them to use prime factorization instead. A computer can still use the list strategy because it won't make a mistake on the 1178th multiple, but even a computer takes a while to do it!

Getting Unstuck strategies that helped me with this project:
Sleeping on it
Going through the code step by step
Avoiding making clones broadcasters! (specific to Scratch)
Using descriptive names for my variables

TIL that if you want two clones to share information (clone-specific variables) then one strategy for this is to make a global variable and have one clone "temporarily" store its info there so that the other clone can act on it. Two clones cannot share information directly with one to another, as far as I can tell.

If I had more time (or if someone wanted to remix this project), I would either use the prime factorization method for both the LCM and the GCF, or for the LCM (which is the long part for large numbers), I would make the program make a list of (say) the 20 first multiples, check if there is an LCM in that list, list the next 20, check again, etc. This should greatly reduce the time necessary for MOST LCM calculations (except when all of the numbers are prime amongst themselves).
instructions:
Find the greatest common factor and the lowest common multiple of two or more numbers.
Enter all the numbers and say "No" or "no" when you are done.
If you use large numbers or 4 or more numbers, the program works but can take over 10 minutes (!), so if Scratch Cat is saying "Hmm..." for a long time but the timer is still advancing... be patient!

title: RPN Calculator
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 17
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I realized a very simple RPN calculator.
The starfish asks the user the data to put in the stack (which is a list) and the operation to perform.
Once an operation is specified it get the last two data from the stack and replace them with the result. The latter is ready to be used as an operand for the next calculation.
instructions:
When I was a child a teacher of mine had a calculator by Hewlett-Packard (HP) where if you want to calculate 2+3 you must type "2", "enter", "3", "+".

I was a bit puzzled... then I studied about it.

The Reverse Polish Notation (RPN) is a notation for math expression where you first put data in a stack and then type the operation you want to perform on the data.
For example, to calculate the sum of 2 and 3, instead of writing "2+3=" you must enter "2", then "3", then "+".
The good thing is the once you calculated a result it take the place of the operands in the stack, so it can be easily used for another operation.
It could sound confusing, but it is actually convenient!
This procedure allow avoiding parenthesis and confusion about operator's precedence.

If you want to calculate a bit more complex expression like:
   (2+3)*7 = 35
You must enter:
2, 3, +, 7, *

Easy! (or not?)

The starfish asks you to type the numbers or symbols you want to enter in the RPN calculator, type each item at once and press enter...

title: Day 17 - making sense of the sum of two dice
description:
This exploration of the game of two dice is inspired to Galileo Galilei "On a discovery concerning dice" where he answer the following question: "Suppose three dice are thrown and the three numbers obtained added. The total scores of 9, 10, 11, and 12 can all be obtained in six different combinations. Why then is a total score of 10 or 11 more likely than a total score of 9 or 12?

https://www.leidenuniv.nl/fsw/verduin/stathist/galileo.htm
instructions:
Click on the roll button to repeat rolling two dice. The "rolls" list contain the sum of the two dice for each roll; the list "roll-count" counts the number of occurrences of each sum.  
Examine the results, can you make an urn that (as a random generator) is equivalent to rolling two dice? Click on the "2dice urn" button to create it.
If you notice that a number (e.g. 6) appears many times, put more 8 in the urn.
Click on the dice to "extract" form the urn and check if this is equivalent the rolling the two dice.

title: Bubblesort - GettingUnstuck-17
description:
Bubblesort is one of many sorting algorithms, not the most efficient, but one of the simplest to implement so it was funny to play with it on Scratch.
This is just the first iteration: I would like to see the bubbles move when I swap them (and just those involved) instead of redrawing all of them like now. I used the parsing function from the day16.
And, thinking about thinking: bubblesort is not the way our brain sorts numbers, what kind of algorithm do we really use? Is it the same for all of us?
instructions:
Green flag to start.
You can enter some numbers comma separated and they will be bubblesorted (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bubble_sort)

title: Program Steven
description:
I wanted to create a todo list for a sprite, then I realized that it is exactly what a computer program is! So I made a very simple programming language on top of Scratch.

I was surprised by how easy it was to build the "interpreter", i.e. the "start" sprite that reads from the list and broadcast messages to Steven. If I had more time I would implement more programming blocks and I would add the possibility of repeat loops.

Enjoy!
instructions: Click on the blocks to create a program, then press the start button to let Steven execute it.

title: Getting Unstuck17 : the rainbow
instructions:
PRESS THE GREEN FLAG 
LIST IN ORDER THE COLORS OF THE RAINBOW
IF YOU FAIL PRESS THE GREEN FLAG AGAIN
WRITE IN BLOCK LETTERS PLEASE

title: An alphabetical story (Getting Unstuck #17)
description:
Getting Unstuck activity #17 - "Create a project that asks the user to type in multiple words or numbers, stores the items in a list, then does something interesting with the items from the list. "

The story sorts the entered names alphabetically and uses them in the stories. I was going to have sprites using the entered names and have different backdrops etc, but the list logic took up too much time.
instructions:
Click the flag. Enter the names and places as prompted and see what story comes out! 

Words expected are:

5 names
3 places

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 17
description: I used a list to add elements of the story to. When the question has been asked multiple times, I loop through the list element by element to extract the lines and have the storyteller sprite say them.
instructions:
You will need three people to play this story game!
You will create a story together with two other people. Each person will have time to write their own line in the story. The trick is that you can only see the previous line. At the end, the storyteller will read the completed story to you.

Press the green flag and follow the instructions.
